questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with fever, malaise, and a bright red "slapped cheek" rash on his face, which later spreads to his trunk and extremities. Blood tests reveal mild anaemia. The clinical diagnosis of erythema infectiosum is made. What are the characteristics of the virus responsible for this condition?

A 35-year-old woman with sickle cell disease presents with pallor, fatigue, and weakness. Her hemoglobin is significantly decreased, with a low reticulocyte count. She reports recent exposure to her child, who had a finding as shown in the image below. Given the virus's specific tropism, which maternal or fetal tissue is primarily affected in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Fetal liver, targeting erythroid progenitor cells

options.label: B
options.text: Fetal bone marrow, affecting myeloid progenitor cells

questions.correct_answer: A. Fetal liver, targeting erythroid progenitor cells
questions.explanation:
Parvovirus

Morphology

  • Simplest animal viruses infecting humans, responsible for erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).
  • Smallest viruses (18–26 nm in size).
  • Non-enveloped with icosahedral symmetry.
  • Only DNA viruses with single-stranded DNA.
  • Dependent on host cell enzymes for replication.

Pathogenesis
  • Exclusively infects humans.
  • Transmission:
  • Primarily through the respiratory route.
  • Blood transfusion.
  • Transplacental transmission.
  • Target Cells: Tropism for erythroid progenitor cells in adult bone marrow and fetal liver. (Option A)
  • Receptor Binding: Binds to blood group P antigen on RBC surface.
  • Effects: Leads to RBC destruction and inhibition of erythropoiesis, potentially causing anemia.

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

German measles (aka Rubella)

4th disease

Duke disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum, HHV-6

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a 5-day history of painful, itchy swelling and erythema of his hands and feet, following mild flu-like symptoms that resolved a few days ago. Examination reveals the following findings, as shown in the image below. What syndrome is this child exhibiting, and which pathogen is it associated with?

options.label: B
options.text: Papular-purpuric gloves and socks syndrome; Parvovirus B19

options.label: C
options.text: Hand, foot, and mouth disease; Coxsackievirus

questions.correct_answer: B. Papular-purpuric gloves and socks syndrome; Parvovirus B19
questions.explanation:
Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:
 
 
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease) (Option A )
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis:
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia. (Option B)

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: A 55-year-old kidney transplant recipient presents with worsening renal function. Urinalysis shows the following finding in the image below. PCR confirms the presence of viral DNA. Which virus is most likely responsible for this patient’s nephropathy?
questions.explanation:
Polyomavirus

MCV
  • Merkel cell polyomavirus.
  • Causes merkel cell cancer.
  • CK7+ & CK 20-ve.

SV40
  • Simian vacuolating virus (SV40)
  • Associated with mesothelioma.

BK virus (Option C)


 


 

BK virus is a polyomavirus with double-stranded DNA, typically causing:

  • Nephropathy in kidney transplant recipients. The time period of nephropathy is after 6 months post-transplant.
  • Hemorrhagic cystitis in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients.
  • Infections in immunocompetent individuals are often asymptomatic.
  • Cytologic examination of urine can reveal “decoy cells”.
  • These characteristic cells have enlarged nuclei with a single, basophilic, intranuclear inclusion, which mimics cancer cells on pap smear.

JC Virus (John Cunningham)

(Option A)

  • Causes Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML

  • Characterized by multifocal demyelination across the brain.

  • Involves the deformation of astrocytes and oligodendrocytes.
  • Primarily occurs in immunocompromised patients and patients taking natalizumab in multiple sclerosis treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female is diagnosed with cervical dysplasia, and HPV testing reveals a high-risk strain. A histopathological examination of her cervical biopsy shows the following findings. Which viral protein is associated with the formation of these findings?
questions.explanation:
HPV is a DNA virus belonging to the Papillomaviridae family.

Tropism: Selectively infects epithelial cells of skin and mucous membranes.

Morphology

  • Non-enveloped virus, 50–55 nm in size.
  • Icosahedral capsid containing circular double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

Viral Genome

Early (E) Region: Includes E1-E7 genes coding for nonstructural proteins.

  • E1 and E2 Proteins: Regulate viral DNA replication. (Option A)
  • E4 Protein: Disrupts cytokeratins to facilitate the release of the virus.
  • E5 Protein: contributes to the formation of perinuclear vacuoles, leading to cytoplasmic “halos.” (Option D)
  • E6 Protein: Promotes degradation of the p53 tumor-suppressor protein. (Option B)
  • E7 Protein: inhibits retinoblastoma protein, contributing to oncogenesis. (Option C)

Late (L) Region: L1 and L2 genes code for structural capsid proteins.

  • Types: Over 100 HPV types, classified by DNA sequences in the L1 region.
  • L1 capsid protein is used for making vaccines.

HPV Mechanism of Oncogenesis
 
  • E6 Protein:
    • Promotes degradation of p53, blocking apoptosis and inhibiting p53-driven activation of tumor suppressor gene p21.
  • E7 Protein:
    • Inhibits the retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor gene through direct RB inhibition and by interfering with p53 and p21 functions.
  • HPV infection alone is insufficient for malignancy; factors such as co-transfection with v-fos DNA, genetic mutations (e.g., mutated RAS gene), & environmental influences (e.g., smoking, microbial co-infections, dietary deficiencies, hormonal changes) enhance cancer risk.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with recurrent hoarseness and difficulty breathing. Laryngoscopy reveals findings, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely HPV serotype associated with these lesions?
questions.explanation:
Types of HPV
 

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
 

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

Cutaneous involvement

Benign Warts
  • Common Skin Warts (Verruca Vulgaris): Small, hard, rough growths on the skin; commonly seen in children (associated with serotypes 2, 4, 27, 57).
  • Flat Warts (Verruca Plana): Also prevalent among children.
  • Plantar Warts (Verruca Plantaris): Benign lesions commonly found in adolescents (linked to serotype 1).

 

Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
  • Rare autosomal recessive conditions may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, especially in sun-exposed areas.
  • Associated with serotypes 5 (Option A), 8, 9, 12, 17, 20, 36, and 47.

Mucosal involvement

Anogenital Warts
 
  • It is also known as Condyloma Acuminatum.
  • A sexually transmitted infection in adults, associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11.

Head and Neck Lesions
 
  • Benign: Recurrent laryngeal papillomas, especially in children (serotypes 6, 11). (Option B)
  • Malignant: Laryngeal and esophageal carcinomas (serotypes 16, 18) (Option C)

Carcinoma Cervix
  • Mainly squamous cell carcinoma linked to high-risk serotypes like 16, 18, 31, 33, and others. (Option D)
  • Serotype 16 alone accounts for ~50% of cases, while serotypes 16 & 18 together cause ~70% of cervical cancers.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for her HPV vaccination with the nine-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil 9). Which of the following HPV types does this vaccine protect against?
questions.explanation:
Laboratory Diagnosis of HPV
 

 
  • Molecular Methods:
    • PCR (gold standard) and hybrid capture assays detect HPV DNA and identify types by targeting E6 and E7 genes.
  • Lesion Detection:
    • Most HPV lesions are visible; 5% acetic acid enhances lesion visibility.
  • Cytologic Evidence:
    • Detected via Papanicolaou (Pap) smears from cervical or anal scrapings show perinuclear cytoplasmic vacuolization termed koilocytosis.
    • Histopathological staining of biopsy samples shows koilocytes with resinoid nuclei.

Bivalent Vaccine (Cervarix)

Covers high-risk types 16 and 18; administered as a single IM dose.

Quadrivalent Vaccine

Includes HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18

Nine-Valent Vaccine (Gardasil 9)
  • Covers 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58. (Option B)
  • Doses:
  • IM at 9-14 months, with 2 doses (6–12 months apart).
  • After age 15, 3 doses (0, 2, and 6 months).
  • Recommended up to age 26 if unvaccinated; better immune response if administered before age 14.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male traveller returns from Central Africa with symptoms of fever and mild skin rashes. On examination, he has lymphadenopathy. He reports having direct contact with wild animals during his trip. Which of the following viruses causes these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Poxviruses

Poxviruses are the largest viruses that infect vertebrates.
 

Morphology

  • Poxviruses measure approximately 400 nm in length and 230 nm in diameter, making them visible under a light microscope.
  • Poxviruses are typically brick-shaped or ellipsoid.
  • They possess an envelope consisting of two lipoprotein membranes (outer and inner), and the outer membrane features ridges.
  • The envelope encases a core, along with two structures of unknown function known as lateral bodies.
  • The core or nucleocapsid is biconcave and shaped like a dumbbell.
  • Poxviruses contain a single linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) genome.
  • They are unique among DNA viruses for replicating in the cytoplasm.


 

Human-Important poxviruses
  • Variola is the causative agent of smallpox, the first disease to be eradicated globally.
  • Vaccinia: Used as a vaccine for smallpox.
  • Molluscum contagiosum Virus: Causes warty lesions known as molluscum contagiosum.





 

Genera classification

  • Orthopoxvirus: Smallpox, monkeypox, vaccinia.
  • Molluscipoxvirus: Molluscum contagiosum.
  • Parapoxvirus: Milker’s nodules, bovine papular stomatitis viruses, etc.
  • Capripoxvirus: Sheeppox, goatpox, lumpy skin disease, etc.
  • Avipoxvirus: Fowlpox, pigeon pox, etc.
  • Leporipoxvirus: Myxoma, hare fibroma, etc.
  • Suipoxvirus: Swinepox virus.
  • Yatapoxvirus: Tanapox, Yabapox viruses.

Monkeypox infections
  • The monkeypox virus belongs to the Orthopoxvirus genus.
  • Monkeypox is a rare zoonotic infection first recognized in captive monkeys in 1958.


 

Transmission
  • Infection likely occurs through direct contact with wild animals.
  • The exact primary reservoir host remains unidentified, but species such as squirrels, rabbits, and rodents can be infected.
 

Clinical features
  • Symptoms resemble those of smallpox but are generally milder.
  • Fever and rash.
  • Lymphadenopathy is a prominent feature in most cases, unlike in smallpox or chickenpox.
 

Complications
  • Respiratory distress
  • Secondary bacterial infections
Vaccination

The vaccinia vaccine can offer protection against monkeypox or lessen its severity.
 

Human-to-Human transmission
  • Transmission between humans is considered limited.
  • Estimates suggest that only about 15% of close contacts of infected individuals become infected.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the physician as he developed lesions on the body, as below. Which of the following statements would be false about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: These are caused by molluscum contagiosum virus

options.label: B
options.text: The lesions can be seen all over the body

options.label: C
options.text: This is transmitted through direct and indirect contact

questions.correct_answer: B. The lesions can be seen all over the body
questions.explanation:
Molluscum contagiosum

Molluscum contagiosum virus is an obligate human poxvirus known for producing characteristic skin lesions. (Option A)






 

Clinical manifestations







 

Lesions:

  • Dome-shaped, pink, pearly wart-like lesions (2–5 mm in size) with a dimple at the center.
  • Lesions can appear singly or in clusters, located anywhere on the body except on the palms and soles.
  • Lesions are umbilicated.
  • Genital lesions are commonly observed in adults.
  • Lesions typically resolve on their own within 3–4 months. (Option D)

 
 

Transmission

  • Primarily affects children, transmitted through direct and indirect contact (e.g., barbers, shared towels, swimming pools). (Option C)
  • Rare instances of sexual transmission have been reported in young adults.

Laboratory diagnosis


 

Molluscum bodies:

  • Characteristic intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions were observed in skin scrapings stained with histopathological stains.
 

Confirmation methods:

  • Electron microscopy
  • PCR
 

Cultivation:

  • The virus cannot be propagated in tissue culture, embryonated eggs, or animals.

Treatment

Surgical removal of the lesions by ablation (by cryotherapy or laser therapy) is the mainstay of treatment.

Cidofovir has been shown to have some efficacy.

questions.text: Smallpox was the first infectious disease to be eradicated globally. All the following factors helped eradicate smallpox except.
questions.correct_answer: D. Cross-infection from animal pox viruses
questions.explanation:
Smallpox virus

  • Smallpox was the first infectious disease eradicated globally, characterized by highly contagious and severe rashes.
  • The disease was caused by two strains: variola major and variola minor.
 

Transmission

The virus enters through the mucous membranes of the upper respiratory tract via aerosol transmission.

Clinical manifestations



 
  • Incubation period: Typically lasts 12 days (ranging from 7 to 17 days) before the appearance of rashes.
  • Rash characteristics:
    • Unique rashes that are distinguishable from chickenpox.
    • Deep-seated rashes that appear simultaneously in affected areas with a slow evolution.
    • Centrifugal distribution: rashes initially affect the palms, soles, and extensor surfaces.
    • The fever subsides with the appearance of the rash.
  • Exanthem progression: the disease featured a single crop of centrifugal exanthems that progressed through several stages:
    • Macular stage: Flat, discolored lesions.
    • Papular stage: Raised bumps.
    • Vesicular stage: Fluid-filled blisters.
    • Pustular stage: Pus-filled lesions.



 

Laboratory Diagnosis


 

Direct detection:

  • Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies known as Paschen bodies can be identified in rash scrapings.
  • Electron microscopy reveals a brick-shaped appearance with a biconcave DNA core.

Egg inoculation:

  • Characteristic pock formation observed on the chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) of chick embryos.

Eradication of smallpox

The World Health Organization declared the eradication of smallpox nearly three years after the last recorded case, on May 8, 1980.







 

Factors that helped the eradication
  • Variola had no animal reservoirs. (Option C)
  • Patients were the only source, and no carriers existed (subclinical disease). (Option A)
  • Characteristic rashes made identification straightforward.
  • Asymptomatic cases did not spread the disease.
  • Global Eradication Program:
    • Launched by WHO in 1967, leading to eradication in about 10 years through international cooperation.
  • Effective vaccination: (Option B)
    • Utilized a freeze-dried form of the live vaccinia vaccine for better stability.
    • Administered via a simple and cost-effective bifurcated needle using the multiple puncture technique.
 

Smallpox

Chickenpox

Incubation period:

12 days

Incubation period:

15 days

Site of rash:

Palm, sole, and extensor surface,deep-seated rash

Centrifugal distribution

Rash:

Superficial and pleomorphic (appear in crops)

Evolution is rapid

Dewdrop rashes with centripetal distribution

Fever:

Subsidies with the appearance of rash

Fever:

Rises with each crop of rash

questions.text: A researcher is studying the vaccinia virus. She notices certain characteristics in the virus that enable it to be used for developing vaccines. In the context of vaccine development, what is a significant advantage of using the vaccinia virus as a vector?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a high pathogenicity, making it suitable for inducing strong immune responses.

options.label: B
options.text: Vaccinia virus can accommodate a substantial amount of foreign DNA.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an entirely natural virus found commonly in the human population.

options.label: D
options.text: The vaccinia virus is only effective against a limited range of diseases.

questions.correct_answer: B. Vaccinia virus can accommodate a substantial amount of foreign DNA.
questions.explanation:
Features

Variola virus

Vaccinia virus

Causative agent

Responsible for smallpox (variola major and minor)

Used as the smallpox vaccine


 

Pathogenicity

  • High pathogenicity (Option A)
  • Infects only monkeys in animal experiments
  • Non-pathogenic to humans
  • May produce mild skin lesions
  • Can be used for studies as its safer to work with
  • Infects monkeys, calves, sheep, and rabbits
 

Eradication
  • Eradicated in 1977
  • WHO declared global eradication on May 8, 1980

The virus is not naturally occurring and is artificially made (Option C)

Antigenic properties

Antigenically identical variants (major and minor)

Changed from cowpox during human passage
 

Research applications

Limited to historical study; No current vaccine use

Extensively studied and serves as a vector for many recombinant vaccines (Option D)

Genetic capacity

N/A

Can accommodate ~25,000 foreign base pairs

Histopathology (Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies)

Inclusion bodies named Paschen bodies are seen

Inclusion bodies named Guarnieri bodies are seen

questions.text: A 14-year-old child is brought by her mother with complaints of redness of the eyes with watery discharge. She also complains of a sore throat and fever and gives a history of being in a swimming pool at school. Which serotype of the virus causing this condition is responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Adenovirus

  • Adenoviruses are non-enveloped DNA viruses characterized by icosahedral symmetry.
  • They feature fiber proteins extending from each vertex, creating a distinctive appearance reminiscent of a space vehicle.

Morphology

  • Adenoviruses range from 70 to 75 nm in diameter.
  • It is composed of 252 capsomers forming an icosahedron.
  • Capsomer Types: Hexons and Pentons.
  • Each penton includes:
    • A penton base anchored in the capsid.
    • A fiber projection consisting of a rod-like portion with a knob at the end.

Clinical manifestations

While many serotypes can cause disease, types 1–7 are the most prevalent.





 

Respiratory infections

Upper respiratory tract infections:

  • Common in children
  • Primarily caused by serotypes 1, 2, and 5. (Option A)
  • In adolescents, serotypes 3, 4, and 7 are responsible for mild infections.

Pneumonia:

  • Types 3, 7, and 21 account for 10-20% of childhood pneumonia cases. (Option D)
  • Serotype 14 is linked to severe pneumonia in healthy young adults.

Acute respiratory disease:

  • Occur as outbreaks, especially in military recruits.
  • Associated with types 4, 7, and occasionally type 3.

Transplant recipients:

  • Serotypes 34 and 35 are frequently isolated from these patients.

Ocular Infections

Pharyngoconjunctival fever:

  • Outbreaks typically occur in children's summer camps.
  • Often referred to as swimming pool conjunctivitis.
  • Associated with serotypes 3, 7, and 14.

Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis:

  • Known as shipyard eye.
  • It is highly contagious in adults.
  • Caused by types 8, 19, and 37. (Option B)

Gastrointestinal Infections

Infantile gastroenteritis:

  • Serotypes 40 and 41 are responsible for 5-15% of viral gastroenteritis cases in young children.

Urinary Tract Infections

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis:

  • Primarily affects children, especially boys.
  • Caused by serotypes 11 and 21.

Swimming pool-associated diseases

Causative agents

Swimming pool granuloma

Mycobacterium marinum (atypical mycobacterium)

Swimmer’s itch

Trematode parasites like cercaria

Swimmer’s ear

Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Staphylococcus aureus

Swimming pool conjunctivitis

Chemical irritants like chlorine

Human adenovirus

Chlamydia trachomatis

Pseudomonas aeruginosa
